III. INVESTIGATION
Rule Code Education
Title
Rule Code & CCI Rule 400.4123
Section (2) Provision shall be made for an appropriate education program
Description in accordance with 1976 PA 451, MCL 380.1 to 380.1853. Each
resident of school age shall be enrolled not later than 5 school
days after admission and continuously thereafter.
Violation Potential Rule or Statute Violation
Type
Allegation Youths at facility do not receive special education services or earn
transferrable credits or high school diplomas.
Investigation I was assigned this investigation on 3/13/24.
Interviews:
I contacted Complainant requesting specific names of youths
impacted by the allegations. She alleged Youth T, Youth E and
Former Youth O are not and/or did not receive special education
at the facility and all have expired IEPs. Complainant expressed a
concern that Youth J, Youth T and Former Youth O are not or did
not earn credits at Havenwyck that transfer to other schools.
Complainant further claimed Former Youth O had an IEP due in
Nov 2023 and felt Havenwyck was responsible for getting it done.
I notified Chief Administrator (CA) of the allegations requesting
information regarding their compliance with the Michigan School
Code referred to in the applicable licensing rule.
I interviewed CA, Teacher 1 and Teacher 2 together via
conference call on 3/14/24. They denied the allegations were true
and reported that Pontiac Public School District is responsible to
provide Individualized Education Planning (IEP) services to the
youths referred to them by Havenwyck. CA stated, “All youths
leave Havenwyck with an accurate transcript.” Depending on their
performance, youths can earn transferable credits and/or high
school diplomas which would be awarded by Pontiac Public
School District or the youth’s high school of origin. CA mentioned
she had already conversed with Complainant about her concerns.
She believes the Complainant misunderstood the responsibilities
and limitations of a child caring institution.
2

Teacher 1 stated referral forms are completed at the beginning of
each school year. Havenwyck completes a form for each youth
identified as having had a previous IEP or disability. These forms
are sent to Pontiac Public Schools and Havenwyck waits for a
response. Due to lingering effects of the COVID epidemic,
Teacher 1 said Pontiac Public Schools has had staffing issues
and sometimes been unresponsive to requests by Havenwyck
teachers on behalf of their students. Teacher 1 and Teacher 2
said they are particularly frustrated with the district as an
expressed need for re-classification of Youth T from (EI)
Emotionally Impaired to Cognitively Impaired (CI) has been
delayed.
I consulted with the current and former licensing consultants
assigned to the facility. Neither were aware of any previous
licensing concerns relative to youth education.
On 3/19/24, I met onsite for three hours with CA, Teacher 1 and
Teacher 2. CA has worked at the facility for 29 years, Teacher 1
for over two years and Teacher 2 for over one year. They
provided the following information verbally:
Havenwyck School is considered a “non-public school” similar to a
religious school. The facility has a licensing capacity of 30 with a
current census of 28. Each classroom has one teacher, two adult
teaching assistants and one tutor for up to 15 students. School
work is tailored to meet each student’s individual needs at their
functioning grade level in each subject through “differential
learning,” a computer lab and 1:2 tutoring. The special needs of
students classified as Emotionally Impaired (EI) are met 24/7
through clinical services and the treatment-oriented milieu
encompassed within the residential program.
Whereas public schools employ psychologists who test, and re-
test identified students every three years to determine special
education eligibility and other professionals who arrange Individual
Education Planning Committee (IEPC) meetings and write reports
for students identified with disabilities, Havenwyck School does
have these capabilities and do not employ school psychologists or
other professionals required for IEPCs. To determine eligibility for
special education for its students, Havenwyck must rely on the
local public school district.
Documents reviewed:
3

• Michigan School Code statute 1976 PA 451, MCL 380.1 to
380.1853 – State of Michigan electronic data base.
• Youth T, Youth E, Youth J and Former Youth O’s educational
records at Havenwyck including report cards and earned credits –
paper files. Youth education records indicate Havenwyck provides
its students an education that is tailored to their current grades
and level of functioning through differential learning, computer lab,
and tutoring. Report cards and credits are earned.
• MISACWIS – State of Michigan electronic data base: MISACWIS
indicates the following MDHHS-referred youths were admitted to
Havenwyck:
Youth E was admitted on 6/24/21 - present.
Youth T was admitted on 1/23/23 – present.
Youth J was admitted on 6/7/22 - present.
Former Youth O was admitted on 1/18/24 and discharged on
3/8/24. Not only was I unable to confirm from the youth’s closed
file that an IEP was due last November, but records indicate Youth
O was at Hawthorn at that time. Records also indicate Former
Youth O only resided at Havenwyck for seven weeks.
• CWLM – State of Michigan electronic data base: CWLM
indicates Havenwyck Impulse Control Disorder has been a
licensed child caring institution for 31 years. Paris Miller, PhD.
assumed the chief administrator role in Jan 2022.
I reviewed 2023/2024 Pontiac Schools referral forms prepared by
Havenwyck teachers requesting assessments and determinations
for their students with histories of special needs.
Analysis Havenwyck collaborates with and must rely on an outside source
(Pontiac Public School District) to perform IEPs and annual
evaluations on Havenwyck students. According to Havewyck
teachers, Pontiac School District is not always responsive to their
verbal and written requests for services for their students.
Teacher interviews and youth education records indicate
Havenwyck provides its students an education that is tailored to
their current grades and level of functioning.
While it is true Havenwyck School does not issue high school
diplomas, it is possible to earn a high school diploma awarded by
Pontiac School District or that youth’s high school of origin.
4

In terms of Former Youth O lacking an updated IEP, it was not
realistic to expect Havenwyck and Pontiac Schools to have
completed the entire process in the seven weeks Youth O was at
the facility.
At this time, there is no evidence indicating Havenwyck School is
in violation of the licensing rule or 1976 PA 451, MCL 380.1 to
380.1853.
CONSULTATION
I strongly recommended CA and both teachers meet in-person
with the superintendent of Pontiac Schools to re-establish a
productive working relationship to ensure that the IEP needs of
applicable students at Havenwyck are being met.
Conclusion Violation Not Established
IV. RECOMMENDATION
Based on investigative findings the facility is in compliance with all applicable
licensing statutes and rules. It is recommended that the current license status be
continued.
